awd_titl_txt: LTREB-Renewal:   Twenty-Nine Years of Tidal Marsh Response to Environmental Change
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States is rapidly losing coastal wetlands, critical ecosystems that nourish fisheries, clean our water and protect us from storms. While some marsh losses result from coastal development, others losses have yet to be fully explained. Marshes can build soil vertically and gain elevation to keep pace with slowly rising seas, but the marsh plants that sustain these ecosystems get stressed when sea level rises too quickly. The amount of sea level a marsh can tolerate depends on other factors that are also changing. For instance, the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is rising. Likewise, pollution from nutrients like nitrogen has increased sharply from preindustrial times. Both increased carbon dioxide and nitrogen tend to make marsh plants grow more, which could help marshes keep up with sea level rise. But they also change the types of plants that grow and it is unknown what effects that will have on marshes. This project asks: how will rising carbon dioxide and nitrogen affect plants and the ability of coastal marshes to keep up with sea level rise? Since about half of the U.S. population lives within 50 miles of a coastline, there is considerable pressure on coastal wetlands and the services they provide. The annual loss of low-lying coastal wetlands lost to open water each year threatens fisheries, wildlife habitat, water quality, and infrastructure. The project will also continue public education and science education programs at many levels, and the research results will be made freely available on a public Smithsonian Institution website. 

To address the central question of this project, the study builds on a thirty-year history of ecological observations at a Chesapeake Bay marsh in Maryland. Measurements of primary production and soil chemistry will be combined with parallel experiments that simulate the future environment by adding carbon dioxide and nitrogen to marsh plots, and comparisons will be made of native to invading plants. The long-term records of this site enable the scientists to document changes in the species composition of plants growing on the marsh over time. At this point, the surface elevation of the soil in the marsh is falling behind local sea level rise, suggesting that this marsh may be in the process of collapsing. The investigators will continue their local measurements, but the results should be generally applicable to coastal wetlands everywhere.

por.por_cntn:
In 2010 with support from NSF we established the Global Change Research Wetland (GCReW), a tidal marsh on the Chesapeake Bay dedicated to understanding how plants, microbes, and water interact to control the future of coastal wetlands in a rapidly changing environment. Data from our experiments are used to improve computer models that forecast the fate of coastal wetlands as climate changes and sea levels rise. We believe that accurate forecasts will help us make decisions that benefit both people and ecosystems.

GCReW is a research facility on the western shore of Chesapeake Bay operated by the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center that is home to several experiments (Figure 1). The site is a 22-ha tidal brackish marsh adjacent to Chesapeake Bay. Because of the high salinity there are a small number of plant species. Our experiments are in areas dominated by the native perennial sedge Schoenoplectus americanus and the native grass Spartina patens. The characteristics of these two species differ widely in ways that help us understand the role of plant traits in determining the fate of whole ecosystems in future environments.

Our NSF-sponsored research supported three long-term experiments that address key uncertainties in tidal marsh responses to climate change. The first experiment began in 1987 to test hypotheses about the ability of plants to grow faster in a future high-carbon dioxide atmosphere; it ran through year 35 with support from NSF and is now the world?s longest continuous climate change experiment. The next experiment began in 2006 to test a new hypothesis that nitrogen availability limits the ecosystem-level response to elevated carbon dioxide. The third experiment was designed to study the ecosystem-level consequences of plant invasion. It focuses on the introduced lineage of the common reed Phragmites australis, a plant with a unique combination of traits that, in contrast to our native species, are favored by both elevated carbon dioxide and nitrogen pollution.

Our NSF-sponsored research over the past decade contributed novel insights into the rules by which plants, microbes, and the physical environment interact, supporting our hypotheses in some cases and rejected them in others. The outcome was a substantial revision of our conceptual model, leading to new hypotheses that we propose to test with ongoing NSF support of the three long-term experiments focused on two manipulations known to have large ecosystem effects: elevated carbon dioxide and nitrogen loading. Our new conceptual model of how coastal wetlands respond to global change places soil elevation as the single most important ecosystem-level variable (Figure 2). Elevation is very sensitive to rates of both plant growth and microbial decomposition. Because soil elevation and sea level determine how stable coastal wetlands are to disturbance, elevation also controls ecosystem services such as wildlife habitat, coastal infrastructure projection, and soil carbon storage.

Our long-term observations indicate that ecosystem responses to elevated carbon dioxide and nitrogen pollution, while large, are themselves regulated by sea level, which we propose is the dominant global change factor. Finally, our new conceptual model identifies plant traits as the most important feature of the system that ultimately determines the ecosystem-level response to global change. These insights were used to refine computer models that forecast tidal wetland resilience to accelerated sea level rise.

The long-term experiments and observations generated by our work has helped inform the growing awareness and interest in coastal wetland or ?blue carbon? ecosystems, and the impacts of accelerated sea level rise on coastal wetlands. The broader impacts of our work have also been substantial (Table 1) by training nearly 100 students in high school, college, graduate school, post-doctoral, and 233 citizens. We published 60 articles, gave 109 presentations, contributed 30 media releases, and gave tours of our study site to 2,217 people.
